question: What is DNS primarily used for in the Internet?
Why is DNS implemented as a distributed system instead of a centralized database?
answers: To reduce CPU usage on clients
To eliminate the need for IP addresses
To avoid single point of failure and scaling issues
To force all queries through routers

question: Which DNS service supports using an alternate name for the same host?
Which DNS feature enables one hostname to map to multiple IP addresses for load distribution?
answers: Replicated Web servers under one name

question: In a typical DNS lookup for www.amazon.com, which server type is contacted first (in the basic hierarchy)?
What is the role of a Root DNS server in name resolution?
answers: Stores all A records for the Internet
Acts as contact-of-last-resort when a name cannot be resolved
Translates MAC addresses to IP addresses
Enforces NAT policies for home networks

question: Who manages the root DNS domain (as covered in the slides)?
How many logical root name “servers” are described in the slides?
What is the responsibility of a TLD DNS server?
answers: Serving domains like .com, .org, and country TLDs

question: What best describes an authoritative DNS server?
answers: A server that always performs recursive resolution for clients
An organization’s DNS server providing authoritative hostname-to-IP mappings
A router that applies NAT to DNS traffic
A server that stores only root zone information

question: When a host makes a DNS query, where is it typically sent first?
Which statement about a local DNS server is correct?
answers: It strictly belongs to the DNS hierarchy
It does not strictly belong to the hierarchy
It is always a root server replica

question: In an iterated DNS query, what does a contacted server usually return if it does not know the final answer?
answers: A referral: the name of another server to contact

question: In a recursive DNS query, who bears the burden of completing name resolution?
Why can recursive queries create concerns at upper levels of the DNS hierarchy?
answers: They can create heavy load at upper levels
They prevent UDP from being used

question: What is the main benefit of DNS caching?
answers: Eliminates the need for authoritative servers

question: What does TTL represent in DNS caching?
answers: Time until a cache entry expires

question: A key risk of DNS caching is that cached entries can be:
If a named host changes IP address, why might the new mapping not be known Internet-wide immediately?
answers: Because old cached entries persist until TTLs expire
Because TLD servers never update records

question: Which server information is typically cached in local name servers (per the slides)?
DNS is described as a distributed database storing what kind of entries?
Which is the correct RR tuple format shown in the slides?
In an NS record, what does the 'name' field represent?
In an NS record, what does the 'value' field represent?
answers: Hostname of the authoritative name server for the domain
Alias name for a canonical name

question: What does a DNS A record map?
What is the purpose of a CNAME record?
answers: Maps a hostname to an IP address
Maps a domain to its authoritative server hostname
Maps an alias name to a canonical (real) name
Maps a domain to an SMTP mail server

question: What does an MX record’s value represent?
answers: Name of an SMTP mail server associated with the name
IP address of a root server

question: Which DNS service is specifically related to email delivery?
Which statement matches the slide’s description of DNS reliability/security goals?
answers: DNS must be centralized to be secure
DNS relies on NAT for reliability

question: Which security properties are explicitly mentioned for DNSSEC in the slides?
Which RFC is referenced for DNSSEC authentication services in the slides?
Which attack targets the DNS by intercepting queries and returning bogus replies?
DNS cache poisoning is associated with which type of attack in the slides?
Which DDoS scenario is described as 'not successful to date' in the slides?
Why can root servers sometimes be bypassed during attacks (per the slides)?
answers: Because local DNS servers cache IPs of TLD servers
Because TLD servers are offline by default

question: Which DDoS target is described as potentially more dangerous in the slides?
Which file provides a static hostname mapping alternative to DNS?
Which file is described as the client resolver configuration listing name servers?
Which path is shown in the slides as a systemd-resolved resolv.conf location?
Which command is listed in the slides for querying DNS?
Which command is listed in the slides for querying DNS (another valid option)?
Which command is listed in the slides for querying DNS (another valid option)?
To obtain a second-level domain name, what must you apply to (per the slides)?
answers: A registrar for the appropriate TLD

question: When registering a domain name, which contact types are mentioned in the slides?
When registering a domain, what is the minimum number of name server hosts suggested?
In the 'Network Utopia' example, what records does the registrar insert into the .com TLD server?
In the example, what type of record is created for www.networkuptopia.com?
In the example, what type of record is created for networkutopia.com mail handling?
Which statement best matches the slide’s description of DNS as an application-layer protocol?
answers: DNS is a link-layer protocol with MAC addressing
DNS is an application-layer protocol for address/name translation
DNS is a transport-layer protocol for reliable delivery
DNS is a network-layer protocol for routing

question: Which of the following is NOT listed as a reason to avoid centralizing DNS?
Which statement about DNS performance is emphasized in the slides?
answers: DNS is rarely used, so milliseconds don’t matter
Almost every Internet transaction interacts with DNS, so milliseconds count
DNS is only used by routers
DNS queries are slower than disk I/O by design

question: What does the slide mean by 'many more reads than writes' in DNS?
answers: DNS records are updated constantly every second
DNS mainly serves queries (reads) far more often than record updates (writes)
DNS disables caching to reduce reads

question: Which server type provides authoritative hostname-to-IP mappings for an organization’s named hosts?
Which part of the DNS hierarchy is responsible for top-level country domains like .vn, .uk, .jp?
What is one drawback of caching mentioned in the slides?
Which description best fits 'best-effort name-to-address translation' in the slides?
answers: DNS always returns the newest mapping instantly
DNS can temporarily return stale mappings until TTLs expire
DNS prevents all spoofing without DNSSEC

question: In an iterated query workflow, which component usually talks to root/TLD/authoritative servers on behalf of the host?
Which pair correctly matches DNS record type to its purpose?
Which DNS record type is most directly used to locate a domain’s mail server?
Which DNS record type is most directly used to find the authoritative name server for a domain?
What is the correct interpretation of an A record's fields (as described in the slides)?
What does a CNAME record’s value contain?
Which is a listed way a local DNS server can answer a query?
answers: Only by contacting the root server every time
From its local cache of recent translation pairs

question: Which OS-specific command is listed in the slides for finding your local DNS server on Windows?
Which OS-specific command is listed in the slides for finding your local DNS server on macOS?
What is one reason DNS is described as organizationally and physically decentralized?
answers: Only one company owns all domains
Millions of organizations are responsible for their records
All records are stored on root servers

question: Which statement about root servers is consistent with the slide notes?
answers: There is exactly one physical root server worldwide
Logical root servers are replicated many times in many locations
Root servers store every organization’s full zone file
Root servers require recursive queries from all hosts

question: Which scenario best matches a DNS spoofing/caching threat mentioned in the slides?
answers: Attacker returns bogus DNS replies to redirect users
Attacker changes the MTU of a tunnel
Attacker forces TCP to use UDP ports

question: Which of the following is explicitly listed as a DNS query tracing/lookup tool set in the slides?
Creating your own subdomains requires coordination with whom (per the slides)?
answers: The administrator of the parent domain

question: When creating your own subdomains, what is emphasized about authority?
answers: Authority becomes local within your organization
Authority moves to root servers only
Authority is removed from DNS entirely
Authority is always handled by TLD registries only

question: Which statement about domain registration fees is consistent with the slides?
answers: Fees are only paid to ISOC
Fees are waived if you run your own DNS server

question: What is the general role of DNS in 'getting your info into the DNS' via a registrar?
answers: Registrar inserts certain records into the TLD server
Registrar encrypts all DNS queries with TLS by default
Registrar assigns you a private IP address range
